trial_identification.studytitle: Randomised controlled trial of paper, online and text message diaries for sexual health data collection from young people
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Randomised controlled trial of paper, online and text message diaries for sexual health data collection from young people

interventions.interventions: Three methodologies of collecting sexual health data in the form of a diary are being compared - paper based, online, SMS (text message). Each will complete diaries weekly for 3 months (13 weeks).
interventions.comparator: There are 3 different study arms, as described above.

primaryOutcome.outcome: The number of diaries submitted by participants of the 13 expected (response rate) and completeness of all questions in each diary as determined by whether or not each question was answered.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Participants acceptability and opinions of diary use determined by a questionnaire giving a range of statements about the diaries for example "the diaries were easy to complete" "the diaries were convenient" which can be rated between strongly disagree and strongly agree

Comparability and reliability of diary information to endpoint questionnaire. Determined by total number of partners, frequency of sex and frequency of condom use, over the sum of the diary period, correlated (using kendall tau) to the total number of partners, frequency of sex and frequency of condom use reported in the retrospective questionnaire (at the endpoint of the study, i.e. 3 months after baseline)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Age 16-29 English language Valid mobile phone and email Self perception of being likely to have sexual intercourse in the 3 month study period
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Age not 16-29 English language not spoken No valid mobile phone and email Self perception of being unlikely to have sexual intercourse in the 3 month study period

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This randomised controlled trial compared SMS, paper and online diaries on response rate, timeliness, completeness of data, and acceptability. The correlation between behaviour reported in diaries and a retrospective questionnaire was also determined.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Victorian Department of Human Services HREC
